title: Psalms Chapter 67 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 67 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 67 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 67.

questions.question: According to Psalms 67:1, what does the psalmist ask God to do?
questions.correctAnswer: Be merciful and bless us
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:1 asks God to be merciful and bless us and cause His face to shine upon us.

questions.question: What is the purpose of God's way being known upon earth according to Psalms 67:2?
options: That His saving health be known among all nations
questions.correctAnswer: That His saving health be known among all nations
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:2 states the purpose is that God's way may be known upon earth and His saving health among all nations.

questions.question: Who does Psalms 67:3 say should praise God?
options: Let all the people praise God
questions.correctAnswer: Let all the people praise God
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:3 says, 'let all the people praise thee,' indicating everyone should praise God.

questions.question: According to Psalms 67:4, what will the nations do?
options: Be glad and sing for joy
questions.correctAnswer: Be glad and sing for joy
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:4 states the nations shall be glad and sing for joy because God judges righteously.

questions.question: Which phrase is repeated in Psalms 67:3 and Psalms 67:5?
options: Let all the people praise thee
The earth shall yield her increase
The ends of the earth shall fear him
questions.correctAnswer: Let all the people praise thee
questions.explanation: Both Psalms 67:3 and 67:5 repeat the phrase 'Let all the people praise thee.'

questions.question: What will the earth do according to Psalms 67:6?
questions.correctAnswer: Yield her increase
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:6 says the earth shall yield her increase when God blesses us.

questions.question: Who is referred to as 'our own God' in Psalms 67:6?
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:6 mentions 'God, even our own God,' referring to the Lord who blesses us.

questions.question: What will happen to 'all the ends of the earth' according to Psalms 67:7?
questions.correctAnswer: They shall fear God
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:7 states that all the ends of the earth shall fear God.

questions.question: What role does God have over the nations according to Psalms 67:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Judge righteously and govern
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:4 says God shall judge the people righteously and govern the nations upon earth.

questions.question: What is the tone of the psalm in Psalms 67:1?
options: A request for mercy and blessing
questions.correctAnswer: A request for mercy and blessing
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:1 is a prayer asking God to be merciful and bless the people.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 67:3 calls for only a select group of people to praise God.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:3 clearly says 'let all the people praise thee,' indicating everyone is called to praise God.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 67:4 ends with the word 'Selah'.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:4 ends with the word 'Selah' as a pause or reflection.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 67:7 says God will curse us and the earth.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:7 says God shall bless us, not curse us.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 67:1: 'God be merciful unto us, and bless us; and cause his face to ______ upon us.'
questions.correctAnswer: shine
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:1 says 'cause his face to shine upon us,' requesting God's favor.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 67:6: 'Then shall the earth yield her ______; and God, even our own God, shall bless us.'
questions.correctAnswer: increase
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:6 says 'the earth yield her increase' indicating fruitful blessing.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 67 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 67 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Psalms 67 teach us about the importance of prayer and asking God for blessing in our daily lives?
options: We should ask God to be merciful and bless us, shining His face upon us.
We should rely only on our own strength without seeking God's help.
Prayer is only necessary during church services.
questions.correctAnswer: We should ask God to be merciful and bless us, shining His face upon us.
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:1 emphasizes asking God for mercy and blessing, and that His face may shine upon us, showing the importance of prayer and seeking God's favor.

questions.question: What biblical principle about evangelism and sharing the Gospel is highlighted in Psalms 67?
options: God’s saving health should be known among all nations on earth.
The Gospel is only for a select group of people.
We should keep God's ways private.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s saving health should be known among all nations on earth.
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:2 teaches that God's ways and salvation are meant to be known across the earth and all nations, highlighting the call to evangelize and share the Gospel.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with thankfulness. Based on Psalms 67, what biblical truth would you share?
options: All people are called to praise God for His goodness and blessings.
Thankfulness is only required on special occasions.
God does not expect us to praise Him publicly.
Praising God is only for spiritual leaders.
questions.correctAnswer: All people are called to praise God for His goodness and blessings.
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:3 and 5 repeat the call for all people to praise God, teaching the importance of continual gratitude and worship.

questions.question: How does Psalms 67 instruct believers about God’s governance and justice?
options: God judges people righteously and governs nations on earth.
God leaves nations to govern themselves without judgment.
Justice is determined by human leaders alone.
God shows favoritism in judging nations.
questions.correctAnswer: God judges people righteously and governs nations on earth.
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:4 explains that God judges people righteously and governs nations, encouraging trust in His justice and leadership.

questions.question: What lesson about stewardship and God's provision can we learn from Psalms 67?
options: When God blesses us, the earth yields its increase.
Provision is unrelated to God's blessing.
We should rely on our own efforts alone for prosperity.
Blessings come only through material wealth.
questions.correctAnswer: When God blesses us, the earth yields its increase.
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:6 teaches that God’s blessing results in the earth yielding its increase, highlighting the connection between divine blessing and fruitful stewardship.

questions.question: How does this chapter encourage believers in humility and dependence on God?
options: We recognize that blessings come from God, our own God, not from ourselves.
We should boast in our own achievements.
Dependence on God is a sign of weakness.
God’s blessings are guaranteed without faith.
questions.correctAnswer: We recognize that blessings come from God, our own God, not from ourselves.
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:6 reminds us that God is our own God who blesses us, teaching humility and dependence on His grace rather than self-reliance.

questions.question: What does Psalms 67 teach about the attitude all nations should have toward God?
options: All the ends of the earth shall fear Him.
Fear of God is only for certain people.
Nations should rely on their own power.
questions.correctAnswer: All the ends of the earth shall fear Him.
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:7 states that all the ends of the earth shall fear God, instructing believers to maintain reverence and respect for God's sovereignty.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 67 indicates that God's blessing only benefits individual believers and not the earth or nations.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:6-7 shows that God's blessing causes the earth to yield increase and that all nations will fear Him, indicating blessings extend beyond individuals.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 67, praising God is a communal activity that involves all people.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:3 and 5 emphasize that all people should praise God, showing the communal nature of worship and praise.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 67 teaches us that God’s _____ shall be known upon earth and among all nations.
questions.correctAnswer: way
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:2 says, 'That thy way may be known upon earth, thy saving health among all nations,' highlighting the importance of God's way being made known.

questions.question: How does Psalms 67 encourage believers to respond when God blesses them?
options: By praising God and sharing His saving health with others.
By increasing material possessions without gratitude.
By ignoring the source of blessings.
questions.correctAnswer: By praising God and sharing His saving health with others.
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:2-3 encourages that God's way and saving health be known among all nations, and all people praise Him, implying gratitude and evangelism.

questions.question: What does Psalms 67 teach about God’s justice and governance over nations and peoples?
options: God judges people righteously and governs the nations.
God leaves nations to govern themselves without intervention.
God favors some nations over others unfairly.
questions.correctAnswer: God judges people righteously and governs the nations.
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:4 notes that God judges people righteously and governs the nations, teaching believers to trust in God's fair rule.

questions.question: A believer is feeling discouraged about the fruitfulness of their work. Based on Psalms 67, what truth can you share?
options: God’s blessing causes the earth to yield its increase, so trust Him for fruitfulness.
Effort alone guarantees success without God's blessing.
Fruitfulness depends only on human planning.
Work is meaningless regardless of blessing.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s blessing causes the earth to yield its increase, so trust Him for fruitfulness.
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:6 teaches that when God blesses, the earth yields increase, encouraging trust in God's provision and blessing for fruitful work.

questions.question: How does Psalms 67 guide believers in their attitude toward God’s mercy and blessing?
options: Believers should humbly ask for mercy and blessing, recognizing their dependence on God.
Believers can demand blessings as a right.
Mercy and blessing are irrelevant to daily life.
God’s mercy is only for a few select people.
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should humbly ask for mercy and blessing, recognizing their dependence on God.
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:1 models a humble prayer asking God to be merciful and bless us, teaching dependence on God’s grace.

questions.question: What practical Christian virtue related to fellowship and worship is emphasized in Psalms 67?
options: All people, not just individuals, are called to praise God together.
Worship is a private act only.
Fellowship is unnecessary for spiritual growth.
Praise is only for when we feel like it.
questions.correctAnswer: All people, not just individuals, are called to praise God together.
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:3 and 5 call on all people to praise God, highlighting the importance of communal worship and fellowship.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 67 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 67.

questions.question: What is the primary request made of God in Psalms 67:1?
options: God be merciful and bless us
questions.correctAnswer: God be merciful and bless us
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:1 explicitly asks God to be merciful and bless the people, and to cause His face to shine upon them.

questions.question: According to Psalms 67:2, what is the purpose of God's blessing?
options: That His way may be known on earth
questions.correctAnswer: That His way may be known on earth
questions.explanation: Verse 2 states the blessing is so that God's way and saving health may be known among all nations on earth.

questions.question: Which literary device is prominent in Psalms 67:3 and 5, where the people are urged to praise God repeatedly?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The repeated phrase 'Let the people praise thee, O God; let all the people praise thee' demonstrates synonymous parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device.

questions.question: In Psalms 67:4, what is the anticipated response of nations to God's righteous judgment?
options: Be glad and sing for joy
questions.correctAnswer: Be glad and sing for joy
questions.explanation: Verse 4 says nations will be glad and sing for joy because God will judge righteously and govern the nations.

questions.question: The phrase 'cause his face to shine upon us' in Psalms 67:1 is a Hebrew idiom best understood as what?
questions.correctAnswer: Showing favor and blessing
questions.explanation: The Hebrew idiom of God's face shining upon someone denotes divine favor and blessing, as seen in the Priestly Blessing (Numbers 6:25).

questions.question: How does Psalms 67 emphasize the universal scope of God's salvation?
options: By including 'all nations' and 'all the ends of the earth'
questions.correctAnswer: By including 'all nations' and 'all the ends of the earth'
questions.explanation: Verses 2 and 7 highlight God's saving health among all nations and that all ends of the earth shall fear Him, underscoring universal salvation.

questions.question: What agricultural metaphor is used in Psalms 67:6 to describe the effect of God's blessing?
options: The earth shall yield her increase
questions.correctAnswer: The earth shall yield her increase
questions.explanation: Verse 6 uses the metaphor of the earth yielding its increase to signify prosperity and blessing.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage echoes the theme of all nations praising God as seen in Psalms 67?
questions.correctAnswer: Revelation 7:9
questions.explanation: Revelation 7:9 depicts a multitude from every nation praising God, paralleling Psalms 67's universal call to praise.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 67 is characterized by a chiastic structure emphasizing blessing and praise.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 67 shows a chiastic structure with blessing framing the central theme of praise and universal acknowledgment of God's reign.

questions.question: What is the significance of the term 'Selah' found in Psalms 67:1 and 4?
questions.correctAnswer: A pause or musical interlude
questions.explanation: 'Selah' is commonly understood as a liturgical pause or musical interlude, emphasizing reflection on the preceding words.

questions.question: Which phrase in Psalms 67 suggests an eschatological hope where all nations recognize God's authority?
options: 'All the ends of the earth shall fear him'
questions.correctAnswer: 'All the ends of the earth shall fear him'
questions.explanation: Verse 7's phrase anticipates a future universal acknowledgment of God’s sovereignty, reflecting eschatological hope.

questions.question: In Psalms 67, the repeated call 'Let the people praise thee, O God' functions primarily as what literary device?
questions.correctAnswer: Refrain
questions.explanation: The repetition in verses 3 and 5 serves as a refrain, reinforcing the communal call to worship.

questions.question: How does Psalms 67 reflect the historical context of Israel's role among nations during the ancient Near East?
options: Israel as a light to the nations through God's blessing
Israel isolated and rejected by all nations
Israel focused only on temple rituals
questions.correctAnswer: Israel as a light to the nations through God's blessing
questions.explanation: The psalm envisions Israel’s blessing resulting in universal knowledge of God’s ways, reflecting the covenantal role of Israel as a blessing to nations.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 67:4 states, 'O let the nations be ____ and sing for joy.'
questions.correctAnswer: glad
questions.explanation: Verse 4 expresses the hope that nations will be glad and sing for joy under God's righteous judgment.

questions.question: True or False: The phrase 'God, even our own God, shall bless us' in Psalms 67:6 emphasizes a universal rather than national blessing.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The phrase underscores God's special relationship with His people ('our own God'), indicating a national blessing that leads to universal recognition.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 67 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 67 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 67:1, what is the initial request made to God?
options: God be merciful unto us, and bless us
God cause his face to shine upon us
God govern the nations upon earth
questions.correctAnswer: God be merciful unto us, and bless us
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:1 explicitly begins with a plea for God's mercy and blessing. This is foundational in Scripture, aligning with themes in Ephesians 2:4-5 and Lamentations 3:22-23 where God's mercy leads to blessing and restoration.

questions.question: What is the purpose of God blessing His people as stated in Psalms 67:2?
options: That thy way may be known upon earth
That thy kingdom may be eternal
That the temple may be filled with glory
That the people may prosper materially
questions.correctAnswer: That thy way may be known upon earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:2 teaches that God’s blessing serves the purpose of revealing His way and saving health among all nations. This reflects the missional theme seen in Matthew 28:19-20 and Romans 15:18-19 where God’s salvation is to be proclaimed globally.

questions.question: Which phrase is repeated in Psalms 67:3 and Psalms 67:5 to emphasize worship?
options: Let the people praise thee, O God
Sing for joy, O people of God
Give thanks to the Lord, for He is good
questions.correctAnswer: Let the people praise thee, O God
questions.explanation: Both Psalms 67:3 and 67:5 repeat the call for universal praise to God, emphasizing worship as central to the community of believers. This is consistent with New Testament exhortations like Hebrews 13:15 and Revelation 19:5.

questions.question: What is the eschatological implication of God judging the people righteously in Psalms 67:4?
options: God will establish justice and peace among nations
God will destroy the wicked without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: God will establish justice and peace among nations
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:4 affirms divine righteous judgment and governance over nations, an eschatological theme echoed in Isaiah 11:4 and Revelation 20:11-12 where God's righteous rule brings peace and justice.

questions.question: According to Psalms 67:6, what is a sign of God's blessing upon His people?
options: The earth shall yield her increase
The nations shall cease from war
questions.correctAnswer: The earth shall yield her increase
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:6 connects God’s blessing with agricultural prosperity, a biblical symbol of divine favor seen also in Deuteronomy 28:12 and Joel 2:23-26, emphasizing God’s providential care for creation.

questions.question: What universal response to God's blessing is predicted in Psalms 67:7?
options: All the ends of the earth shall fear him
The mountains shall sing for joy
The seas shall roar with praise
questions.correctAnswer: All the ends of the earth shall fear him
questions.explanation: Psalms 67:7 teaches that God's blessing leads to universal reverence, aligning with themes in Psalm 22:27 and Philippians 2:10 where all creation acknowledges God's sovereignty.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'God be merciful unto us, and ______ us; and cause his face to shine upon us.' (Psalms 67:1)
questions.correctAnswer: bless
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly requests God to be merciful and bless His people. This blessing is a key concept throughout Scripture, such as in Numbers 6:24-26 and Ephesians 1:3.

questions.question: What does Psalms 67:4 say about the nature of God's judgment?
options: God shall judge the people righteously
God shall judge only the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: God shall judge the people righteously
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes God's righteous judgment over all people, reflecting His just character as portrayed in Deuteronomy 32:4 and Acts 17:31.

questions.question: What is the significance of the nations being glad and singing for joy in Psalms 67:4?
options: It signifies universal acknowledgment of God's righteous rule
It indicates political alliances among nations
It reflects a harvest festival celebration
It symbolizes the end of war
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies universal acknowledgment of God's righteous rule
questions.explanation: The gladness and singing of nations point to global recognition of God's just governance, a theme also found in Psalm 96:11-13 and Isaiah 52:7.

questions.question: Which of the following best summarizes the theological theme of Psalms 67?
options: God’s blessing leads to global praise and reverence
God’s judgment is limited to Israel
God’s mercy is only for the righteous
God’s face is hidden from the nations
questions.correctAnswer: God’s blessing leads to global praise and reverence
questions.explanation: Psalms 67 highlights God's blessing resulting in worldwide knowledge, praise, and fear of Him, consistent with Psalm 96:1-3 and Romans 15:11.

questions.question: What does the repeated call for 'all the people' to praise God suggest about the scope of worship in Psalms 67?
options: Worship is inclusive of all nations and peoples
Worship is only for the priests
questions.correctAnswer: Worship is inclusive of all nations and peoples
questions.explanation: The repetition in Psalms 67:3 and 67:5 underscores universal worship, echoing the global mission in Isaiah 49:6 and Revelation 7:9.

questions.question: According to Psalms 67:2, what is meant by 'thy saving health'?
questions.correctAnswer: God’s salvation and deliverance
questions.explanation: 'Saving health' in this context refers to God's saving grace extended to all nations, a theme consistent with Exodus 15:26 and John 3:17.

questions.question: In Psalms 67:7, the phrase 'all the ends of the earth shall fear him' suggests what about God's sovereign rule?
options: God’s sovereignty is universal and acknowledged globally
God's rule is limited to Israel
God's sovereignty is hidden from most people
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sovereignty is universal and acknowledged globally
questions.explanation: This verse affirms God's universal authority and the reverential fear due to Him worldwide, supported by Psalm 22:27 and Philippians 2:10.

questions.question: What is the significance of the instruction 'cause his face to shine upon us' in Psalms 67:1?
options: It symbolizes God's favor and presence
It means God will reveal secret knowledge
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God's favor and presence
questions.explanation: The shining of God's face is a biblical metaphor for favor and blessing seen in Numbers 6:25 and 2 Corinthians 4:6, indicating God's gracious presence.

questions.question: How does Psalms 67 reflect the doctrine of common grace?
options: God’s blessing extends to all nations, leading to praise and fear of Him
God’s grace is only for the elect
questions.correctAnswer: God’s blessing extends to all nations, leading to praise and fear of Him
questions.explanation: The psalm shows God's blessing bringing knowledge and praise among all peoples, a reflection of common grace as seen in Matthew 5:45 and Acts 14:17.
